headline.main: Afraid to Speak Up at the Doctor's Office

docs.abstract: Patients felt limited to certain ways of speaking with their doctors, and many believed they were best served by acting as "supplicants" toward the doctor "who knows best," according to a new study.
docs.snippet: Patients felt limited to certain ways of speaking with their doctors, and many believed they were best served by acting as "supplicants" toward the doctor "who knows best," according to a new study.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eco-immunology seeks both to understand the immune systems of wild animals and to use that knowledge to gain a better understanding of human immune systems.

headline.seo: Eco-Immunology Charts Pathways of Disease in Nature
headline.main: In Wild Animals, Charting the Pathways of Disease
headline.print_headline: In Wild Animals, Charting the Pathways of Disease

docs.abstract: Dr Raina K Plowright is among a growing number of scientists studying eco-immunology, discipline that works to understand how disease spreads in wildlife populations, with goal of applying that knowledge to the human immune system; animal disease research was until recently confined to genetically similar specimens in laboratories.
docs.snippet: Eco-immunology seeks both to understand the immune systems of wild animals and to use that knowledge to gain a better understanding of human immune systems.

docs.lead_paragraph: Like AIDS, the authors of an editorial argue, Chagas disease is stigmatizing, has a long incubation time and is hard or impossible to cure.

headline.seo: Spread of Chagas Is Called ‘The New AIDS of the Americas’
headline.main: Stubborn Infection, Spread by Insects, Is Called ‘The New AIDS of the Americas’
headline.print_headline: Chagas Disease: Stubborn Infection, Spread by Insects, Is Called ‘The New AIDS of the Americas’

docs.abstract: Editorial in journal PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases calls Chagas disease 'the new AIDS of the Americas'; disease, which is caused by parasites transmitted to humans by blood-sucking insects, has a long incubation time, is hard to detect, and is nearly impossible to cure.
docs.snippet: Like AIDS, the authors of an editorial argue, Chagas disease is stigmatizing, has a long incubation time and is hard or impossible to cure.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last summer I went to my local Department of Motor Vehicles to renew my driver's license. When it was my turn after a half-hour wait, a woman behind the counter summoned me, muttered a greeting and began shuffling through my papers. After a few minutes she broke the silence and asked, ''Do you want to be an organ donor?''

headline.main: Awaiting A License, Thinking Of Death

docs.abstract: Dr Pauline W Chen essay laments the low rate of organ donors in the United States, especially among blacks; cites study in the Annals of Internal Medicine that found more people sign up to be organ donors at their DMV after viewing a video that dispels common myths and vividly portrays the need for donations. (M)
